Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 tacking on 0.7%. The IBD 50 rose 0.9%. Volume was lower on both major exchanges. The March 26 distribution day on the S&P; 500 fell off the count…

Accenture (ACN) early Thursday delivered earnings for its fiscal second quarter that beat analyst estimates, fueled by increasing demand for digital and other technology services, as shares hit a record high. The company's cautious revenue outlook for the current quarter, however, dipped below analysts views. Still, Accenture stock was up more than 5% in early trading in the stock market…

Global consulting firm Accenture (ACN) is holding just below a recent buy point ahead of its fiscal Q2 earnings report next week. The stock broke out past a 91.54 buy point from a shallow cup-with-handle pattern on March 5. Volume, though, was only 26% above average. Shares hit a new all-time high that day, but were not able to follow through.
The stock fell as much as 6% below the buy point, nearly triggering a sell signal. Shares have since recovered, though, retaking the 50-day line and approaching the old high.
Accenture provides consulting, technology and outsourcing services in more than 120 countries across the globe. It has offices in 200 cities and employs more than 300,000 people.

It will report fiscal second-quarter results before the open on Thursday. Analysts expect earnings per share of 1.07, up 4%, on a 4% gain in revenues. It would be the slowest earnings and sales gains in four quarters. Still, it would mark the 10th straight quarter of positive year-over-year growth in both sales and earnings.
Accenture pays a semi-annual dividend with a current yield of 2.3%. IBD calculates an annual dividend growth rate of 33%.

It is part of the highly rated Computer-Tech Services industry group. With an 82 Composite Rating it ranks near the middle of the 43-stock group. Group leaders by Composite Rating include Epam Systems (EPAM), Tyler Technologies (TYL) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH).
Fewer than half of the stocks in the group pay a dividend, however, and Accenture sports the highest yield among stocks with at least a 50 Composite Rating.

Accenture has been on an acquisition spree in 2015. Most recently it completed an acquisition of Gaspo, an analytics solution provider based in Brazil. On Feb. 9 it bought Agilex Technologies, a provider of digital solutions and IT services for U.S. government agencies.Global consulting firm Accenture (ACN) is holding just below a recent buy point ahead of its fiscal Q2 earnings report next week. The legendary value investor increased his long-term bet in beaten-down IBM (IBM), tracked in IBD's Computer-Tech Services group. He also announced a new position…

The dot-com bubble burst had a lot to do with technology stock mutual funds' underperformance relative to the top two sectors — real estate and energy — as well as the S&P 500 during the past 15 years.Look at the result of investing $10,000 in the average tech mutual fund on Dec. 31, 1999. The sum would have shrunk to $9,896 by Feb. 10 this year, according to Morningstar Inc. data. But the same amount would have grown to $58,115 in the average domestic real estate fund, $45,490 in the average world energy fund and $18,772 in the S&P 500.Tech mutual funds have fared better since the stock market low of March 2009. They've generated a cumulative return of 88% since then vs. 78% for real estate funds, 16% for energy funds and 97% for the S&P 500.Fidelity Select IT Services Portfolio has provided investors an average annual return of 10.02% the past 15 years vs. 4.53% for the S&P 500. The fund, managed by Kyle Weaver since 2009, and the S&P 500 are up less than 1% year to date. The $860 million fund's recent holdings include Visa (V), MasterCard (MA) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH).Visa has an IBD Composite Rating of 93. Fiscal Q1 earnings rose 15%, beating analyst estimates. The credit card processing company's full-year earnings are seen growing 19%, slightly below their three-year average pace of 20%.MasterCard has a Composite Rating of 94. Q4 earnings rose 21%, surpassing estimates. Full-year earnings are expected to growth 13%, below the three-year rate of 18%.Cognizant has a Composite Rating of 99. Earnings in the past three quarters have slowed to a range of 12%-14% from 18%-22% the prior three periods. Analysts see 13% growth in the current quarter as well as the full year.The provider of tech services and business process outsourcing has been focusing on building its health care and life science practice.

Accenture (ACN) just boosted its digital marketing capabilities. The management consulting, technology service and outsourcing company said it completed its acquisition of Reactive Media, which it calls a leading Australian digital marketing agency, on Sunday. Terms were not disclosed. Accenture announced its intention to acquire Reactive on Dec. 2. Accenture stock was down a fraction in the stock market today,…

Some big-cap stocks stepped up to new highs Wednesday despite a late sell-off in the major indexes. Dow component Walt Disney (DIS) surged 8% in huge volume. Shares gapped higher at the open, in response to fiscal Q1 earnings and revenue that easily topped consensus views. The stock is now 11% past a 91.30 buy point cleared in late October.…
The strength in the U.S. markets this year hasn't been in small caps, but IBD's Big Cap 20 hasn't benefited much from that trend.
Small caps, as measured by the S&P 600, are up 6% in 2014 vs. 15% and 13% for the Nasdaq and S&P 500 respectively. However, the Big Cap 20 is up only 5% for the year.

More recently, the whole group of indexes pegged a short-term low Dec. 16. The Big Cap 20 is up 4% since then, lagging the 6% gains by the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 in the same period. And the small cap S&P 600 is up 7%, leading the market at least for this brief spell.
This week's Big Cap 20 is, in some ways, a study in frustration.
Some stocks in the Big Cap 20 have been hot-and-cold stories.
For example, Biogen Idec (BIIB) sketched a flat base from November 2013 to early January. The biotech stock broke out Jan. 10 and advanced 20% to a high in March.

A key IBD rule is to take profits when a stock is up 20% to 25%. Most stocks will begin to consolidate after such a gain. Individual investors who locked in the 20% profit are probably glad they sold.
Biogen hasn't been able to do much since that March high. The stock broke out in July and December without gaining much.

Other medical stocks in the Big Cap 20, such as EpiPen maker Mylan (MYL) and prescription-drug manufacturer Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX), sketched similar action in 2014. This doesn't mean the stocks failed to deliver good returns in 2014. Biogen is up 23% for the year; Mylan, 33%; and Valeant, 22%. However, it does mean if an investor missed the early gains, there wasn't much left to play.
Outside the medical sector, things haven't been much better.

Tech services provider and business processes outsourcer Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) regained its 50-day line in February and then rose about 11%. The stock began to consolidate in March and hasn't made much progress since.
Action has been choppy, which doesn't inspire confidence.
Is there a bright spot amid any of the consolidation stories?
LinkedIn (LNKD) raises some interesting questions because its story is different. Of the stocks mentioned above, LinkedIn is the only one expected to step up earnings growth in 2015.
The Street expects 2014 EPS to roll in with a 20% increase. In 2015, estimates see growth cranking up to 43% for the Internet platform for business professionals.
LinkedIn delivered some good runs in 2013. But the stock began 2014 amid a downward consolidation. LinkedIn has now sketched a flat pattern with a potential buy point at 238.87.

The stock could be suffering from overhead supply (buyers on the left side of the pattern looking to sell). Or it could be that the long consolidation drove out the weak holders.The strength in the U.S. markets this year hasn't been in small caps, but IBD's Big Cap 20 hasn't benefited much from that trend.Small caps, as measured by the S&P 600, are up 6% in 2014 vs. 15% and 13% for the Nasdaq and S&P 500 respectively. Epam Systems (EPAM) is well positioned to continue to capitalize on the growing global information technology service market. That's the view of Jefferies analyst Jason Kupferberg, who initiated coverage on the technology outsourcing service company Thursday with a buy rating and a price target of 62. Epam stock was up 5% in midday trading in the stock market today, near…
Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) continues its plan to grow its life science practice through acquisitions.

The provider of tech services and business process outsourcing said Tuesday that it has acquired Cadient Group, a privately held digital marketing agency, to help build Cognizant's health care and life science practice. Terms were not disclosed.
Cognizant stock was up a fraction in early trading in the stock market today, near 44.
Cadient provides digital marketing services for pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical device firms, hospitals, health care systems and related institutions and associations.
The deal follows Cognizant's announcement last month that it hasagreed to acquire TriZetto, a provider of health care IT software and related services, for $2.7 billion in cash.

Cadient's digital marketing services will add an important element to Cognizant's life science practice, says Shankar Narayanan, vice president and global markets leader of Cognizant's life sciences practice. Cognizant's life science practice accounts for about $2.5 billion in annual revenue.

"The life sciences industry is undergoing structural disruption as marketing services enable new digital ways for companies to engage with patients and providers and create compelling user experiences," he said in the company's press release. "In an increasingly competitive industry with many digitally active stakeholders, the acquisition of Cadient Group will complement Cognizant's digital and interactive solutions capability.
"It will help brand marketing leaders to innovatively transform their brands, manage customer experience across multiple channels, maintain quality standards and comply with regulations."

Of 24 firms that have reported so far this quarter, 20 beat estimates, two missed and two met. That's an 83% beat rate,…

Medical issue Illumina (ILMN) is just within a 5% buy zone from a 192.27 buy point from a double-bottom base. Since an Oct. 22 breakout, it has moved mostly sideways…

France-based Publicis Groupe late Sunday announced it's agreed to acquire Sapient for $3.7 billion in a move to speed up its push into digital advertising. Sapient stockholders will receive $25 in cash per share, a 44% premium to Sapient's close on Friday. Sapient was up 43% in early trading in the stock market today, near 25. Boston-based Sapient stock had…
Healthy third-quarter results sent Cognizant Technologies (CTSH) up more than 8% Wednesday and placed investor attention on a number of India-related stocks.

Cognizant, which began as the Indian IT arm of Dunn & Bradstreet, is a world citizen. Headquartered in Teaneck, N.J., it has the bulk of its operations, two-thirds of its 150,000 employees, still in India. More than 75% of its revenue comes from the U.S., however, with another 18% coming from Europe.

An IT services monolith with revenue expected to clear $10 billion this year, it reported that Q3 earnings and revenue each rose 12%, narrowly topping consensus forecasts. But management guided fourth-quarter EPS and revenue growth above expectations, due to spending increases among financial services and health care clients.
Investors responded by sending shares 2% past a 51.48 buy point in a double-bottom base. The base is a bit awkward, long and flattish, but it is only a second-stage structure.

India-based stocks generally rose Wednesday. Icici Bank (IBN) added 2% in solid trade, its 12th gain in the past 14 sessions. The stock ended nearly 6% above a 55.47 buy point in a flat base. It is set to clear its prior high set in November 2010.
HDFC Bank (HDB) tacked on a fraction. It has gained in eight of nine recent sessions, and is 2% above a 51.77 buy point in a cup base.

One India-based leader still in a base is Tata Motors (TTM). The automaker has built a handle with a 47.30 buy point on a nine-week cup base. The base is a second-stage pattern, suggesting that the stock still has room to rally.
Tata reported October sales that were down 17%. Fiat Chrysler Automotive (FCAU) reported a 22% U.S. sales jump. General Motors (GM) sales rose a fraction. Ford (F) sales slipped 2%.

The bulk of Tata's sales are in India. It also owns the Jaguar and Range Rover names, which generate more than 80% of company revenue. Supply shortages of the two luxury brands hurt U.S. sales in October, with Range Rover sales slipping 15% and Jaguar sales down 34%. Tata's sales in India slumped 20%.

But Jaguar/Land Rover are launching a spate of new products in 2015. New models in India are expected to gain traction. And Tata is likely to be a leading beneficiary of programs by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to boost domestic manufacturing and consumer demand.Healthy third-quarter results sent Cognizant Technologies (CTSH) up more than 8% Wednesday and placed investor attention on a number of India-related stocks.Cognizant, which began as the Indian IT arm of Dunn & Bradstreet, is a world citizen. It has gained in eight of nine recent sessions, and is 2% above a 51.77 buy point in a cup base.One India-based leader still in a base is Tata Motors (TTM). The automaker has built a handle with a 47.30 buy point on a nine-week cup base. The base is a second-stage pattern, suggesting that the stock still has room to rally.Tata reported October sales that were down 17%. Fiat Chrysler Automotive (FCAU) reported a 22% U.S. sales jump. General Motors (GM) sales rose a fraction. Ford (F) sales slipped 2%.The bulk of Tata's sales are in India. It also owns the Jaguar and Range Rover names, which generate more than 80% of company revenue. Supply shortages of the two luxury brands hurt U.S. sales in October, with Range Rover sales slipping 15% and Jaguar sales down 34%. Tata's sales in India slumped 20%.But Jaguar/Land Rover are launching a spate of new products in 2015. New models in India are expected to gain traction. And Tata is likely to be a leading beneficiary of programs by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to boost domestic manufacturing and consumer demand.

Several Big Cap 20 stocks have recently broken out of bases, but are still within buy range, or are building new bases and could be good additions to a watch list. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) has pulled back and is within the 5% buy zone. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base Oct. 23 with double the usual volume. Going…

Today it's a $36 billion company, by market cap, with 161,000 employees operating around the world. It's a wide-ranging company involved in consulting, technology and outsourcing. Sales growth fuels earnings growth, and earnings growth fuels price performance. It's a simple concept, but investors often ignore it.
While blue-chip names garner headlines, many are missing a key ingredient seen in major market winners: a consistent track record of big earnings and sales growth.
Most blue chips had it in their early stages, but growth eventually slows. So newer companies that are still expanding their market share are a good place to look.
Plenty of companies can talk the talk, promising big earnings and sales growth down the line, but those that can walk the walk with a steady track record of large growth are harder to find.
So when someone tells you about the next "can't miss" stock on Wall Street, make sure that there's a legitimate growth story surrounding the hype.

Inconsistent quarterly and annual results can be a result of sketchy demand for a product or poor execution by management. That's not a trait seen in past big market winners. The market's best stocks showed consistently strong growth before and during their lengthy uptrends.

Choppy results can also come from cyclical or defensive stocks that tend to do well under specific economic circumstances. These stocks can make decent gains, but the big money is made by focusing on firms that are still in the early stages of growth and are providing a genuinely innovative product or service.

In IBD's New America section, company profiles highlight firms showing big earnings and sales increases. Many are still in the early stages of growth. Fast-growing firms are also prominent in the IBD 50, Your Weekly Review and IPO Leaders screens, among others.
Target stocks with high Earnings Per Share, SMR (Sales + Profit Margins + ROE) and Composite Ratings from IBD. They generally show a consistent track record of growth in recent quarters.

IBD's Computer-Tech Services group, for instance, is full of strong price performers with solid fundamentals. Of course, some companies are faring better than others. Dow component IBM (IBM) still gets a lot of attention in the financial media, but it's been a laggard for some time now, mostly due to weak earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. IBM has been lagging the market badly; its Composite Rating is 50.
Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), on the other hand, continues to see strong demand for its tech outsourcing services. Its Composite Rating is 98.
Cognizant's annual earnings have increased every year since at least 2006. The company has strung together at least 18 straight quarters of double-digit earnings and sales growth.

Some firms that make these IBD screens are turnaround stories. After a period of laggard price performance and sluggish earnings and sales, some firms shift gears well and adapt to new conditions in an industry. Business ramps back up, and growth-fund managers start accumulating the stock. In this case, sluggish growth followed up by two to three quarters of big growth are signs that a turnaround is underway. Successful turnarounds can be a launching pad for big price gains.Sales growth fuels earnings growth, and earnings growth fuels price performance. Accenture turned in a mixed bag of earnings results for its fourth quarter and outlook for the current quarter. But the numbers, released before the market opened Wednesday, weren't enough to appease some investors. Accenture (ACN) stock fell nearly 2% in early trading on the stock market today. Accenture is a leading global management consulting, technology and outsourcing services company…
Stock futures pointed to a narrowly mixed open for the stock market today amid economic worries.
Nasdaq 100 futures rose 2 points vs. fair value, while S&P 500 futures slipped 1 point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 7 points.

Stocks racked up two distribution days last week and snapped five-week win streaks. The distribution count now stands at three for both of the major indexes, which isn't too bad. But any more in a short period of time would be negative.

In economic news, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development trimmed its U.S. growth projection to 2.1% from 2.6% for this year. For 2015, the OECD cut its growth forecast to 3.1% from 3.5%.
And over the weekend, China release data showing that industrial output climbed 6.9% in August from a year ago, the slowest pace in six years.

The Empire State factory survey surged to 27.5 in September from 14.69 in August. That's the highest reading in about five years and easily beat the forecast of 15.9. But futures had little reaction to the report.
Data on industrial production and capacity utilization for August will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET.
But the main piece of economic news will be the two-day Fed meeting, which starts Tuesday. The central bank's policy statement will be out Wednesday.

On the corporate front, RadioShack (RSH) jumped 15% in premarket trade on news that CFO John Feray stepped down after less than a year at the struggling retailer. The company lost money in the past two years, while sales fell by double digits.

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) agreed to buy health care IT firm TriZetto for $2.7 billion in cash. The deal is expected to immediately add to non-GAAP earnings. Cognizant shares rose nearly 3% in premarket trading.

Elsewhere, Adobe Systems (ADBE) will report fiscal Q3 results after the close. The software giant is expected to deliver earnings of 26 cents a share, down 18% from a year ago. The stock market made a modest bounce at midday Wednesday, erasing early losses.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3% while the S&P 500 and Dow each rose 0.2%. Volume was tracking higher across the board.
Tesla Motors (TSLA) broke out of a cup-shaped base. The electric-car maker rose past the 244.59 buy point. Volume was tracking more than double its average.
The company said Tuesday it resolved a trademark dispute in China, which had threatened to complicate Tesla's growth plans in that country.
A number of Chinese stocks that have rallied recently were up in the stock market today.

YY Inc. (YY) climbed 2% in heavy trading ahead of its earnings report after the close. It rose back above the 78.83 buy point of a cup with handle in what has been a seesaw breakout attempt. BitAuto (BITA), meanwhile, rose 4% to a new high in active trading. The car-marketing company is well extended from a breakout past 45.45 on June 17.

Some energy stocks were up in heavy trading, such as Halliburton (HAL), Concho Resources (CXO) and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD). All three are trying to reclaim their 50-day lines. Concho reports earnings after the bell.

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) plunged 14% in huge volume. Shares are now well below a base pattern that had been forming since March. Accenture (ACN) leveraged growth in its consulting and IT outsourcing businesses to report fiscal Q3 earnings and sales Thursday that topped Wall Street expectations, but gave mixed guidance for the current quarter.
Accenture fell 1.8% in late morning trade in the stock market today. Accenture stock fell 5% three months ago, when fiscal Q2 missed analyst views.

For the quarter ended May 31, Accenture reported earnings per share minus items of $1.26, up 4% from $1.21 in the year-earlier period. Last year's EPS figure included a benefit of $50 million or 7 cents a share derived from a reduction in reorganization liabilities, the company said in its earnings release.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.21.
Revenue rose 7% to $7.74 billion, whereas analysts had expected $7.54 billion.
For the current quarter, the company expects revenue of $7.45 billion to $7.70 billion, up 5.2% to 8.7%. The midpoint edges analyst estimates of $7.54 billion.

Analysts expect EPS ex items of $1.15, up 14%. Accenture doesn't provide an EPS outlook for the quarter, but the company narrowed its EPS guidance for the year to $4.50 to $4.54 vs. its previous forecast of $4.50 to $4.62. Given that Accenture beat Q3 EPS views by a nickel, lowering the full-year midpoint by four cents implies Q4 EPS of just $1.08.
Analysts expect $4.53, up 7.6%.

Accenture's consulting revenue rose 6% to $4.09 billion and outsourcing jumped 10% to $3.65 billion, which indicates the company is exhibiting growth across several sectors, Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said in the release.

"These results clearly demonstrate that we are successfully executing our growth strategy," he said. "We are leveraging our unique positioning at the intersection of business and technology, capturing new opportunities in key growth areas — especially digital — and investing to further differentiate our capabilities."

Accenture rivals include IBM (IBM), and they are the two largest companies in IBD's Computer Tech-Services group, which ranks just No. 134 of 197 industries tracked. IBM fell 0.6% in late morning trade. Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), the U.S.-Indian tech consultancy, fell 1.8%.

Stocks opened lower in solid trade Tuesday morning.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 dipped 0.3% each. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.2%.
Volume in the stock market today was up 2% on the Nasdaq and 6% higher on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.
Wholesale inventories climbed 1.1% in April, according to the Commerce Department. That was equal to March's gain and well above forecasts for a 0.2% increase.

The Labor Department reported unfilled jobs rose to 4.46 million in April. The monthly Job Turnover and Labor Openings survey had shown 4.01 million open positions in March. Economists had projected a slight rise, to 4.03 million unfilled openings, for April.
In stocks, leaders staged a milquetoast open, with just over three in five IBD 50 stocks dipping at the starting bell.

Qiwi (QIWI) opened down 8%. The operator of kiosk-based financial service, primarily in Russia, on Monday cleared the 46.47 buy point on a handle in a deep, double-bottom base with an 8% surge on Monday. Tuesday's move drove shares back below that entry. Qiwi announced late Monday an offering of nearly 9 million American depositary shares.

Facebook (FB) popped 3% in early trade. Reports said David Marcus, president of Ebay's (EBAY) PayPal subsidiary, was moving to Facebook, where he would become vice president of messaging products. Facebook has been climbing the right side of a consolidation since early May. Shares were trading 13% below their March high. EBay shares slipped 3% in early action.

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) slumped 3% after Susquehanna downgraded the stock to neutral from positive. The report maintained the stock's 55 price target. The software outsource services provider has, for the past month, been trying to climb out of a three-month-old consolidation.Stocks opened lower in solid trade Tuesday morning.The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 dipped 0.3% each. Cognizant Technology Solutions endured a weak IT spending environment, health care industry changes and other issues to post first-quarter sales that just met views and per-share profit 7 cents better than expected.The global information technology consulting and outsourcing firm's outlook mirrored its Q1 with revenue slightly below views and a per-share profit 4 cents ahead of views. But investors weren't satisfied. Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) stock fell 4.4% to 47.02 on the news Wednesday.Cognizant's results followed mixed results from two rivals. Infosys (INFY) reported revenue slightly below estimates while its per-share profit arrived just above views for its fourth quarter. Accenture's (ACN) fiscal Q2 results fell short of analyst estimates on the top and bottom lines.Cognizant's results still look promising against the austere IT spending backdrop and when compared against recent year-over-year quarterly growth rates of 1% for Accenture and 12% for Infosys, Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Jamie Friedman said."It's tough out there in IT and IT services," he said. "This is actually better than expected. Pretty much everyone in this group has been missing their numbers and they have been missing at a much lower growth rate."During a conference call, Cognizant President Gordon Coburn said several issues conspired to limit revenue growth in Q1. They included the federal Affordable Care Act, aka ObamaCare; leadership changes at some health care company customers; and heavy storm activity in North America in the early part of year, he said."There was no single cause for these headwinds," he said. "It was a confluence of several factors."Investors could be jumping the gun by dumping shares, Janney Montgomery Scott analyst Joseph Foresi says."It's important to keep in mind (that) March is typically the seasonally slow quarter because IT budgets are specifically set for that particular quarter," he said. "Secondly, discretionary spending (by customers) was off to a better start this year than last year, which means the environment is pretty good."The slight miss on the revenue outlook for Q2 also shouldn't be too alarming, Foresi says."The guide was not as exciting as people had wanted but I think the fundamentals are still very much in place," he said.In the quarter ended March 31, Cognizant reported a per-share profit of 62 cents, minus items, up 21.5% vs. 51 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 55 cents.Revenue rose 20% to $2.42 billion, matching views.For the current quarter, the company expects a per-share profit, ex items, of 62 cents vs. 50 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts were modeling for 58 cents.

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) will attempt to do one better than its rivals when it reports first-quarter results Wednesday before the market opens. The global outsourcing and consulting services company's earnings report is set to arrive amid mixed results from rivals such as Infosys (INFY), which reported revenue slightly below estimates and a per-share profit just above views, while Accenture's…

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) might be in a better position than some of its rivals to cash in on what could be a lukewarm IT spending environment this year. Bangalore, India-based software developer Infosys (INFY) stumbled Wednesday after management softened expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter.
The stock tumbled 6%, slicing below its 10-week moving average in three times its average trade. Volume soared 344% above its 50-day average.

Industry peer Cognizant Technology (CTSH) dived 3% in opening trade, but found support at its 10-week line and recovered to a 1.4% loss. Founded in India, Cognizant is now headquartered in the U.S., but has more than two-thirds of its 150,000-person workforce in India.

Cognizant is India's No. 2 Internet technology services firm, ranked by revenue. Infosys is No. 3. The largest, by a wide margin, is Tata Consultancy Services, a subsidiary of India's massive Tata Group.

Infosys Chief Executive S.D. Shibulal, speaking at a Barclays investors conference in Bangalore, said clients reporting slowdowns across various industries led to "unanticipated project ramp downs and cancellations in Q4 (ending in March)," as reported by India's Business Standard.

Shibulal also pointed out "mismatches between skills that clients need and what we have." Combined, the factors are leading to a "decline in business momentum," suggesting the company might only meet the low end of its full-year revenue guidance range.

The company has seen healthy demand in its core regulatory compliance and risk-related services. Demand from retail, and for high-technology offerings — the largest sub-segment within Infosys' manufacturing division — has continued to see resistance, according to the Standard.

The stock ran up 62% from a June low of 38.91, boosted by rising confidence in management's efforts to revamp the company's offerings. Infosys' third-quarter EPS rose 7%, better than expected and ending a four-quarter string of declines.

Analysts call for a 6% earnings slip for the year ending in March, followed by a 12% gain in fiscal 2015. Cognizant has done a better job at tapping what analysts say is rising demand in India's IT services sector. It grew EPS 17% for the year ended in December, with forecasts for an 11% gain this year. Cognizant has grown quarterly earnings steadily since at least the end of 2009.

Narayana Murthy, Infosys executive chairman, said Wednesday that the company grew 5% per year in 2012-13 vs. an 11% rate for the industry as a whole.Bangalore, India-based software developer Infosys (INFY) stumbled Wednesday after management softened expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter.The stock tumbled 6%, slicing below its 10-week moving average in three times its average trade. Stocks opened narrowly mixed on Friday, as the currency effects stirred by China early in the week settled and oil prices imposed some mild upward pressure on the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Nasdaq was effectively flat in early action.
Trading got off to a soft start in the stock market today, with volume down 11% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE.

Oil prices were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate up more than 1%, and Brent crude down a fraction. WTI was tracking toward a steep loss for the week, while Brent was up about 1%. Energy stocks will be keeping an eye out for Baker Hughes' weekly rig count, which is due out at 1 p.m. ET.

The Labor Department reported earlier producer prices rose 0.2% in July, up 0.3% minus energy and food. That was slightly above expectations and below June's 0.4% gain — showing inflation continuing to run below the 2% pace the Fed says would trigger a rate increase.

Industrial production popped 0.6% in July, the Federal Reserve reported, while downgrading June's increase to 0.1% from 0.2%. Consensus views looked for a 0.4% jump in July. Capacity utilization eased slightly to 78% vs. 78.4% in June and forecasts for 78.1%.
August consumer sentiment cooled, putting the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index at 92.2 for the month, down from 93.1. and disappointing expectations for an increase to 93.5.
In stocks, Nordstrom (JWN) led the S&P 500 index, followed by a long list of energy and oil-related companies. DuPont (DD) led the Dow with a 1.4% gain.

Chip equipment makers were under some early pressure after Applied Materials (AMAT) reported fiscal Q3 earnings in line with consensus expectations, but revenue and Q4 guidance below forecasts. Applied dropped 3%, deepening its five-month correction. Smaller peer ASML Holding (ASML) also fell 3%, setting a new low in its two-month consolidation.

A weak Q2 earnings report didn't keep China-based WuXi Pharmatech (WX) from surging 5% at the open. A management group landed a $3.3 billion deal to buy the provider of clinical trials for drugmakers, in a deal that would take the company off the U.S. stock market. The company gave no timeline for the $46-per share deal to be completed. The gain punched the stock back above its 50-day moving average, leaving it just below its mid-May high.

Three out of five leaders opened lower on the IBD 50 list. CyberArk Software (CYBR) led the upside after Wells Fargo upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Shares remain below their 10-week moving average in a two-month consolidation and below a prior buy point of 69.10.

Losses were narrow, with Tesoro's (TSO) 1% slip being the deepest cut. The refiner was trading 7% below the new high notched on Thursday.Stocks opened narrowly mixed on Friday, as the currency effects stirred by China early in the week settled and oil prices imposed some mild upward pressure on the market.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Nasdaq was effectively flat in early action.Trading got off to a soft start in the stock market today, with volume down 11% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE.Oil prices were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate up more than 1%, and Brent crude down a fraction. WTI was tracking toward a steep loss for the week, while Brent was up about 1%. Energy stocks will be keeping an eye out for Baker Hughes' weekly rig count, which is due out at 1 p.m. ET.The Labor Department reported earlier producer prices rose 0.2% in July, up 0.3% minus energy and food. Demand remains strong in the field of tech outsourcing because its value proposition isn't hard to convey: It saves companies time and money. In IBD's tech services industry group, large-cap names like IBM (IBM), Infosys (INFY) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) tend to get the lion's shares of headlines. But an under-the-radar, small-cap company in the group has plenty going…
Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2%.
Volume rose, up 8% on the Nasdaq and 3% higher on the NYSE, compared with volume levels at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today launched with the S&P 500 tearing a hole in support at its 200-day moving average, around the 2075 level. The index took a quick breath of air above its 50-day line on Monday and Tuesday before dropping back into its repeated pattern of 200-day tests begun June 29. In that time the index has finished two sessions below that line of support, on July 8 and 9. The Nasdaq is trading just below its 50-day moving average.
U.S. economic news was relatively minor, with the Labor Department's June Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey narrowing to 5.24 million unfilled positions vs. 5.35 million open jobs in May.

New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley, speaking in Rochester, N.Y., said it was early to judge what was going on in China, that the country's currency could have been appreciating alongside the dollar and in need of adjustment.
"Obviously if the Chinese economy is weaker than maybe what the Chinese authorities anticipated, it's probably not inappropriate for the currency to adjust in consequence to that weakness," he said.
The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports its July budget at 2 p.m.
The Dow opened almost unanimously lower. Only Chevron (CVX) rose, up 0.2%, aided by a 1% rebound in oil prices. Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE), JPMorgan (JPM) and Boeing (BA) fell more than 2%.

On the S&P 500, Fossil (FOSL) and Yahoo (YHOO) were worst hit, down 5% each. Fossil reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue growth and Q3 guidance. Yahoo's drop is likely attributable to its 384 million share stake in Alibaba, which has said it will spin off at some point as a separately traded entity.

At the top of the S&P 500, banking and payment software technologies firm Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) jumped nearly 6% after announcing it would pay $9.1 billion to acquire SunGard Data Systems. The privately held SunGard had registered for an initial public offering in June. The company reported $4.67 billion debt as of June 30. National reported that the cash-stock deal would create a company with $9.2 billion in combined revenue. Wednesday's gain hoisted shares to just below a 68.99 buy point in a shallow, five-month cup base.

China-based e-retail giant Alibaba (BABA) retreated 7% in opening trade after its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, while a 28% revenue jump stopped short of projections and the growth of total gross volume slowed to 34%. Management launched a two-year, $4.6 billion share buyback initiative. The loss put shares 40% below their November high and 6% above their September IPO price.

Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA), a leading developer of video processing chips, skidded 4% lower, to the bottom of the IBD 50 list. Key client GoPro (GPRO) was also 4% lower in early trade. Stocks were lower near midday Wednesday following disappointing jobs data and a warning by Federal Reserve head Janet Yellen that equity valuations were "quite high."

The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were each down 0.3%. All three indexes are now below their 50-day moving averages. Volume was running 15% higher on the Nasdaq but was fractionally lower on the NYSE compared with Tuesday.

Yellen, speaking at a conference in Washington, said, "Equity market valuations at this point generally are quite high," adding that "there are potential dangers there." However, she said she doesn't see any bubbles forming.
Meanwhile, private U.S. employers added 169,000 jobs in April, the fewest since January 2014, according to payroll processor ADP. The government's key nonfarm payrolls report for April is due Friday.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) weighed on the Nasdaq, sliding 1% in heavy volume. Early in the session, the iPhone maker fell nearly 8% below a 133.70 flat-base buy point. A key IBD sell says to sell a stock if it falls 8% below the purchase price.

Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped 8% after the biotech company said it would buy Synageva BioPharma (GEVA) for $8.4 billion in cash and stock. The acquisition values Synageva at $230 a share, more than double Synageva's closing price Tuesday. Synageva was up 115% at midday.

Meanwhile, game developer Electronic Arts (EA) rose 4% to a new high following a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report.Stocks were lower near midday Wednesday following disappointing jobs data and a warning by Federal Reserve head Janet Yellen that equity valuations were "quite high."The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were each down 0.3%. Synageva was up 115% at midday.Meanwhile, game developer Electronic Arts (EA) rose 4% to a new high following a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report.
Cognizant Technology Solutions' growth story ran afoul of a seasonal speed bump.
Shares of the global outsourcing and consulting services company fell about 4% Wednesday after it delivered in-line results that left investors wanting more.
Its outlook for the current quarter offered much of the same. The company's expected profit was in line with views while its revenue forecast was barely ahead of estimates.

Cognizant Technology Solutions' (CTSH) results come on the heels of mixed results last month from two rivals. Infosys (INFY) soundly beat estimates for its fiscal third quarter, while Wipro (WIT) missed on revenue but beat its EPS target by a penny.

During a conference call with analysts early Wednesday before the market opened, Francisco D'Souza, Cognizant's chief executive, said the company's fourth quarter "played out exactly how we expected it" due to expected reductions in discretionary spending by select business segments.

"Historically, our fourth quarter has been a slow quarter . . . typically the retail sector doesn't begin any new discretionary projects during the peak season and discretionary spending overall tends to slow towards the end of the year," he said.
In the quarter, Cognizant reported a per-share profit of $1.06 vs. 92 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.06.
Revenue grew 21% to $2.35 billion vs. the same quarter last year. Analysts had expected $2.36 billion, or growth of 22%.

For the current quarter, Cognizant said it expects a per-share profit, ex items, of $1.18 (prior to an upcoming 2-for-1 stock split) vs. 93 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts have been targeting $1.10.
The company said it expects revenue of at least $2.42 billion, up 20% vs. the year-earlier period. Analysts expect $2.41 billion.
Cognizant also expects revenue for the year of at least $10.3 billion, up 17% from 2013.
But investors probably wanted more upside in the forecast, says Rahul Bhangare, an analyst for William Blair & Co. Bhangare has an outperform rating on the stock.
"They guided to about $10.3 billion and the Street was at about $10.4 billion, but I think the consensus was a bit too aggressive," he said. "I think the fourth-quarter results were fine."
Others agreed.

In a report released Wednesday, Janney Capital Markets analyst Joseph Foresi said the company's conservative guidance "should help keep investor sentiment in check," but has no bearing on the company's internal operations. He has a buy rating on the company.
"Cognizant remains well positioned to capitalize on an improving spending environment that should drive results and multiples throughout the year," he wrote.
As in prior quarters, the company's financial services accounted for the largest share of revenues, making up 42% of total sales.
In the quarter, financial services grew 22% to $997.1 million vs. the same quarter last year.
Health care ranked second with $613.2 million, up 23%.
Revenue from manufacturing/retail/logistics increased 20% to $490.2 million.

During the call, D'Souza said Cognizant is deriving much of its revenue from helping customers integrate social media, mobile, analytics and cloud-based computing technologies into their respective businesses.
"These technologies are enabling our clients to re-imagine and redesign part or all of their business models," he said.
And it's not surprising to see financial services companies continue to constitute the bulk of its revenue, Bhangare says.
"Generally, financial services firms are heavy users of technology and outsourcing is a very natural way to reduce costs on the IT side of things," he said.
In the quarter, revenue from North America rose 18% to $1.81 billion vs. the same quarter last year.
United Kingdom revenue increased 19% to $245.9 million, while revenue from the rest of Europe climbed 52% to $183.1 million.
Total revenue from Europe reached $429 million, up 32%.
Revenue from the rest of the world increased 27% to $109 million vs. the same quarter last year.
Europe likely will continue to be a growth driver for the company, D'Souza says.

"We think there is a large under-penetrated market in Europe," he said. "We feel good about Europe going into 2014."Cognizant Technology Solutions' growth story ran afoul of a seasonal speed bump.Shares of the global outsourcing and consulting services company fell about 4% Wednesday after it delivered in-line results that left investors wanting more.Its outlook for the current quarter offered much of the same. Big Data, cloud-based computing and successful challenges against rivals Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and IBM (IBM) could fuel a better-than-expected fourth quarter from Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) when the company reports its results before the market opens Wednesday. Cognizant is a leader in global IT consulting and outsourcing services for financial services, health care, manufacturing, retail and logistics business segments. Though down…

Stock futures stepped off firm gains ahead of Thursday's open as the market looked to wrap up its holiday-shortened week.Dow futures were 60.1 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures jumped 18.8 points. S&P 500 futures were ahead 8.8 points and rising. Small caps had also improved, with Russell 2000 futures turning early losses into a 1.3-point gain.The payroll report is the top piece of U.S. economic news for the stock market today, but eyes remain sharply focused on Greece, where a referendum vote on Sunday could determine whether the country will remain part of or exit the eurozone. Greece's prime minister and finance minister have made clear they are firmly in favor of a "no" vote, which would refuse the so-called austerity measures demanded by eurozone creditors in exchange for continued bailout support. Europe's top stock indexes in Frankfurt and Paris were effectively flat near midsession, while London's FTSE 100 edged up 0.4%.U.S. nonfarm payrolls expanded by 223,000 in May, the Labor Department reported. That was a sharp downtick from April's downwardly revised total of 254,000 new jobs, and below expectations for 230,000 new hires. Private employers accounted for all the additions, with the labor force participation rate down 30 basis points to 62.6% and the unemployment rate dipping to 5.3%, from 5.5% in April and below forecasts for 5.4%. Average hourly earnings were flat, below expectations for a 0.2% gain.Initial jobless claims rose to 281,000 for the week ended June 27, a 3.6% increase over the prior week. Consensus forecasts called for a slight decrease to 270,000. The four-week moving average increased to 272,750, its first increase in three weeks.May factory orders data are due from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET.Early stock action showed online international money transfer service Xoom (XOOM) vaulting 23% in premarket trade. EBay (EBAY) subsidiary PayPal announced after Wednesday's close it would acquire the San Francisco-based startup for approximately $890 million. EBay announced last week it would complete its spinoff of PayPal as a separately traded entity on July 17. EBay shares rose 1%.Tesla Motors (TSLA) jumped 4% ahead of the open. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based car and battery maker reported its sales of Model S sedans rose 52% in the second quarter vs. the year-ago period. The result topped the company's own best-case estimate of 11,000 vehicles by about 500 units. Tesla shares ended Wednesday up 48% from a March low, in a possible nine-month cup base.IBD 50 stock Centene (CNC) rose 2% after agreeing to buy Health Net (HNT) in a cash and stock transaction valued at $6.8 billion. Centene said the deal included $500 million in debt and would boost the company's earnings by 20% in the first year. Centene is extended, recovered to new highs after a high-volume stab through its 10-week line flashed a sell signal in April. Health Net shares spiked 15% before Thursday's open.Overseas, China's mainland markets took another steep step down. The Shanghai Composite shed 3.5% Friday for a 6.6% loss for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng edged up 0.1%, down 1.4% for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 1% and took a weekly loss of 0.1% through Thursday.The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro, up against the yen. In commodities, oil rose a fraction, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate just above $57 a barrel and down almost 5% vs. last Friday's settle price. Gold dipped to near $1,161 an ounce Friday, down a bit more than 1% for the week. Wheat, which has had a volatile week, was slightly higher and trading up nearly 4% for the week at $5.84 a bushel.
Stocks were lower in comparatively firm trade at Thursday's open, despite a healthy increase in November construction spending.
The Nasdaq buckled 0.7%, weighed down by Apple 's (AAPL) 1% slip. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 fell 0.6% each.
Early volume jumped 70% on the Nasdaq and 90% on the NYSE compared with weak levels early Tuesday.
The stock market today received mixed economic news before the open, as weekly jobless claims declined, but only due to a sharp upward revision to the prior week's numbers.

Construction spending rose 1%, month over month, in November, the Commerce Department said, and was up 5.9% over November 2012 levels. Spending on private construction rose 2.2%, while public projects saw a 1.8% decrease. The numbers were in line with economist projections.

Growth in the nation's manufacturing activity moderated in December, according the Institute For Supply Management's PMI Index, which eased to 57 for the month vs. November's reading of 57.3. The result was also in line with forecasts.
In stocks, Garmin (GRMN) slumped 2%, continuing its recent weakness. The maker of digital navigation gear has been correcting since early December and below 50-day support since Dec. 11.
Outsourced software developer Cognizant (CTSH) backed off 2% in heavy trade. The stock has notched new highs for three straight weeks following a rebound from the 10-week line.

Among leaders, Qiwi (QIWI) jumped 3% to grab an early lead among IBD 50 stocks, but gave up most of it. The provider of online payment kiosks in Russia is extended and working on a fourth straight weekly gain. It is 229% above its May IPO price.

Ambarella (AMBA) dropped 4%. 3D Systems (DDD) and MasterCard (MA) head the list of five leading big-cap stocks that ended 2013 at all-time highs, making them worth looking at for 2014.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, institutional-quality stocks that are highly liquid and have excellent fundamentals.
Five of them ended the year on a high note: 3D Systems, MasterCard, Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), Mohawk Industries (MHK) and Alliance Data Systems (ADS).
3D Systems makes 3D printers, devices that use software blueprints to make a widening array of goods ranging from toys and appliance replacement parts to walls for homes.
The company along with rival Stratasys (SSYS) pioneered the hot category, which is growing rapidly as businesses adopt them for manufacturing and consumers start snatching them up too.

In early December, an analyst with Canaccord Genuity raised his price target on 3D Systems, saying "revenue growth is being driven by strong organic demand, a continuing expansion of new products, looming consumables growth acceleration, and an expanding consumer channel."
Shares of 3D Systems, which have nearly doubled since early October, rose 1% Tuesday to 92.93.
MasterCard had an outstanding year, as did larger rival Visa (V), which isn't on the Big Cap Leaders list.

MasterCard's global credit card transactions climbed to 10 billion last quarter amid a more positive economic climate. If its earnings per share growth hits Wall Street's 23% target this quarter, it will have had at least four years of double-digit profit growth.
MasterCard sports a best-possible 99 Composite Rating. Shares rose less than 1% to an 835.46 close in Tuesday trading on the stock market today.

Francisco D'Souza helped spin off Cognizant Technology Solutions, a tech consulting and outsourcing company, from Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) in the late 1990s and was named Cognizant's CEO in January 2007.

Despite the Great Recession, he's overseen its growth from $1.4 billion in revenue that year to a projected $8.4 billion in 2013. D'Souza told IBD in a recent interview, "I think the key to success in the business world today is to learn how to adapt quickly."
BNP Paribas forecasts that Cognizant's revenue will hit $10.3 billion in 2014.

Flooring and rugmaker Mohawk Industries has been growing in sync with the housing recovery. Credit Suisse was among a group of analysts that raised their ratings on Mohawk in December after the company posted accelerating EPS growth of 50%, 61% and 94% in the first three quarters of 2013.

Private-label credit card issuer Alliance Data Systems provides card services to chains such as Hilton Worldwide (HLT), which began trading as a public company again in December, Williams-Sonoma's (WSM) Pottery Barn and L Brands (LB), parent to Victoria's Secret. Consensus is for EPS to climb 27% this quarter.
In December, Alliance Data Systems and Mohawk got a further lift when they were included in the widely followed S&P 500, triggering more accumulation by index funds that track the S&P.

3D Systems (DDD) and MasterCard (MA) head the list of five leading big-cap stocks that ended 2013 at all-time highs, making them worth looking at for 2014.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Big Cap Leaders, institutional-quality stocks that are highly liquid and have excellent fundamentals.
Five of them ended the year on a high note: 3D Systems, MasterCard, Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), Mohawk Industries (MHK) and Alliance Data Systems (ADS).
3D Systems makes 3D printers, devices that use software blueprints to make a widening array of goods ranging from toys and appliance replacement parts to walls for homes.
The company along with rival Stratasys (SSYS) pioneered the hot category, which is growing rapidly as businesses adopt them for manufacturing and consumers start snatching them up too.

In early December, an analyst with Canaccord Genuity raised his price target on 3D Systems, saying "revenue growth is being driven by strong organic demand, a continuing expansion of new products, looming consumables growth acceleration, and an expanding consumer channel."
Shares of 3D Systems, which have nearly doubled since early October, rose 1% Tuesday to 92.93.
MasterCard had an outstanding year, as did larger rival Visa (V), which isn't on the Big Cap Leaders list.

MasterCard's global credit card transactions climbed to 10 billion last quarter amid a more positive economic climate. If its earnings per share growth hits Wall Street's 23% target this quarter, it will have had at least four years of double-digit profit growth.
MasterCard sports a best-possible 99 Composite Rating. Shares rose less than 1% to an 835.46 close in Tuesday trading on the stock market today.

Francisco D'Souza helped spin off Cognizant Technology Solutions, a tech consulting and outsourcing company, from Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) in the late 1990s and was named Cognizant's CEO in January 2007.

Despite the Great Recession, he's overseen its growth from $1.4 billion in revenue that year to a projected $8.4 billion in 2013. D'Souza told IBD in a recent interview, "I think the key to success in the business world today is to learn how to adapt quickly."
BNP Paribas forecasts that Cognizant's revenue will hit $10.3 billion in 2014.

Flooring and rugmaker Mohawk Industries has been growing in sync with the housing recovery. Credit Suisse was among a group of analysts that raised their ratings on Mohawk in December after the company posted accelerating EPS growth of 50%, 61% and 94% in the first three quarters of 2013.

Private-label credit card issuer Alliance Data Systems provides card services to chains such as Hilton Worldwide (HLT), which began trading as a public company again in December, Williams-Sonoma's (WSM) Pottery Barn and L Brands (LB), parent to Victoria's Secret. Consensus is for EPS to climb 27% this quarter.
In December, Alliance Data Systems and Mohawk got a further lift when they were included in the widely followed S&P 500, triggering more accumulation by index funds that track the S&P.
Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Related:Ambarella, Jazz Among Stocks Outpacing Record Market.

The 50-day line is shaping up as a battlefield for many Big Cap 20 stocks.Ideally, a stock's trip back to its 50-day line, or 10-week line as some prefer, should be in quiet volume. If the stock bounces off the line in fast trade, then a secondary buy zone can be established.In some instances, an entry at the 50-day line can be an early buy in what eventually becomes a base.For example, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which was No. 9 in the Big Cap 20 on Dec. 10, returned to its 50-day line in mid-December. Volume was quiet on the descent.On Dec. 20, the stock bounced off the line in twice its usual volume. Investors could have bought anywhere from 516 to 533 that day.Chipotle consolidated for about three weeks after its bounce off the line — completing a cup-with-handle base. The entry was 537.10.Although a Jan. 9 breakout came in volume 65% above average, the stock never found further traction. The breakout failed.Investors who bought on the 50-day bounce might have eventually exited the trade with a small profit. Those who bought at the breakout lost money.The point here isn't that the 50-day line is preferable to a breakout. But the case does illustrate that the key area can sometimes give the investor one more tool in how to play a stock.A number of stocks on Monday's preliminary list for the Big Cap 20 are battling at the 50-day line.Facebook (FB) retreated to its 50-day line over four sessions. The first three days involved losses in below-average volume. On Monday, volume picked up, and the stock bounced up after touching the line. At its nadir, the stock fell almost 6% below its 54.93 buy point.Priceline (PCLN) made a 52-week high last week and then pulled back. On Monday, Priceline sliced under the 50-day line in heavy volume.Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) retreated to the 50-day line in above-average volume. However, on Monday the stock rebounded off the line in strong volume.Celgene (CELG) broke under its 50-day line in fast trade Friday and lost more ground Monday.Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) is back at the 50-day line, but hasn't made a decisive move above or below the line.Google (GOOG) made a decent move up off the 50-day line Monday, after briefly violating the line. Volume was strong.Netflix (NFLX) closed under its 50-day line for 11 straight sessions and then gapped above the line in big volume Thursday. The stock recrossed a 368.75 buy point and is in a buy zone up to 387.19.A softening market could define the outcome of these battles at the 50-day line. However, should the Federal Reserve deliver a surprise Wednesday when its two-day meeting concludes, that could become the deciding factor.

You've got to respect and understand the classics.In books, there's "The Great Gatsby." In the realm of American food, you've got the burger and fries. And when it comes to chart reading, the most classic pattern is the cup with handle.For decades now, investors who know how to spot this pattern have been reaping profits.The best way to become more familiar with any stock chart pattern is by looking at examples. So it's worth studying the cup-with-handle base that Cognizant Technology (CTSH) formed in 2004.The left side of the pattern began to take shape in January 2004, as Cognizant embarked on what ended up becoming a seven-week losing streak. (1) It wasn't until June that Cognizant began etching the right side of its base.In general, a cup-with-handle structure should be at least seven weeks long. But it could also form over the course of a year, or an even longer period of time.The correction within the cup typically should not exceed 35%, and Cognizant fit the bill as it corrected 31%.The handle part of the base represents one last shakeout of weak shareholders before the stock moves to new highs. You generally want to see calm action and just a mild correction within the handle.A good handle will correct only 8% to 12% or less. You might see a slide of up to 15%, but anything beyond that definitely is not ideal. In Cognizant's case, the handle — which began to develop in July — featured a correction of 14%. (2)A handle also should be at least a week or five trading days in length, although they can be longer. Cognizant took about four weeks to sketch its handle.With any breakout from a base, you want to see strong turnover as the stock moves out of the consolidation. Cognizant certainly delivered convincing volume as it broke out past a 26.74 entry in late July 2004 in big volume. (3)However, with the market in poor shape, Cognizant fell more than 8% from that buy point. Investors had to sell and cut losses.The market returned to a confirmed uptrend Aug. 18. The stock rallied again and cleared the 26.74 buy point for good. It also formed a tighter two-week handle in September, offering a new chance to add shares.Some chartists might think Cognizant's pattern also resembled a double-bottom base. But the middle peak in April was a bit low.

In the 16 years that Gordon Coburn has worked at Cognizant Technology Solutions, the firm has ballooned from about 1,000 employees to more than 145,000. To manage such explosive growth, Coburn and his team seek to preserve organizational culture.

For Coburn, president of Teaneck, N.J.-based Cognizant (CTSH), the key to protecting the information technology consulting firm's culture is creating an environment where employees can apply themselves fully and succeed. That means articulating a vision and then getting out of their way.

"We empower people to run their piece of the business and make sure they have the tools they need," said Coburn, 48. "Otherwise, you become a bottleneck. To get and keep good people, you can't micromanage them."

He adds that a culture of empowerment depends on the quality of the staff. Hiring self-starters with technical prowess and people skills paves the way for better results. Coburn says the best people "have judgment, intellect and fire in the belly."
Tapping Internal Know-How

Coburn's appreciation of the value of empowerment set in early in his Cognizant career. As head count grew, he realized he no longer knew everyone's name within the firm — and that he had to step back so they could step up.

Giving employees the space to succeed is especially important today. In 2011, Cognizant hired an average of 20 people every business hour during the year, Coburn says. Establishing what he calls the "tone from the top," characterized by transparency and clear communication, has enabled the company to grow so fast without losing its identity.

To harness its expanding brain trust, the company launched "Cognizant 2.0" around five years ago — a global collaborative platform for employees to share knowledge. Through this online tool, staffers can connect with internal experts and discuss learning experiences with customers.
Thanks to this repository of internal knowledge, employees preserve institutional memory and best practices. They can answer each other's questions and read case studies and white papers.

"We want it to be process-dependent, not people-dependent," Coburn explained. "We want the process to be replicated so that it's not dependent on a particular individual. So we document with care what's done and why it's done."

If a customer faces a recurring problem with an application, for example, the Cognizant employee who fixes it the first time will describe the steps he or she took — entering the solution into Cognizant 2.0 — so that other workers can follow the same process in the future.

Because a majority of Cognizant's workforce is under age 30, they are adept users of social media. Cognizant 2.0 appeals to younger employees in part because it involves crowdsourcing and other online social networking activities.

"Many of our employees are on Facebook Sunday night," Coburn said. "We want to make their Monday morning experience like their Sunday night experience."In the 16 years that Gordon Coburn has worked at Cognizant Technology Solutions, the firm has ballooned from about 1,000 employees to more than 145,000.
